p: Table 2 shows the statistical comparisons between the observations and the modeling results from PREMET. OBS and SIM are represented the observation and simulation. For T 2, the model slightly overvalues T 2 at all sites, which might result from the uncertainty of urban canopy and surface parameters [ 28, 29, 36, 37]. However, the overestimation is acceptable because the MB values of T 2 are only 0.5–1.7 °C, the RMSE of T 2 is 2.8–3.9 °C, and the CORR between observations and simulations are over 0.8 at all sites (statistically significant at the 95% confidence level). Moreover, the lowest value 0.5 °C for MB and the highest value 0.9 for CORR show that the best simulation of T 2 is at NJ. For RH 2, though the modeling results are slightly underestimated, the CORR values are over 0.8 at most sites. Therefore, the simulations for RH 2 are relatively acceptable. The lowest value 0.7 for CORR is at SH, which may be attributed to the uncertainty of the land-use data that cannot well describe waters around SH [ 29]. For WS 10, the modeling values are overestimated at HZ and SH but underestimated at NJ. The CORR (close to 0.5) for WS 10 is the lowest in three meteorological factors. The wind components were not simulated very well, just as in previous studies, which may be caused by urban canopy parameters [ 28, 29, 37]. Compared with previous studies, the biases in this study are acceptable.
